nodes.title: Test lo-fi detection on charlie.flac
Lo-fi detection approach
nodes.description: How to distinguish MP3 brick-wall cutoff from natural tape/lo-fi rolloff

nodes.title: Approach A: Temporal Cutoff Variance
nodes.description: Measure how cutoff frequency varies over time. MP3=fixed, Tape=varies. Key metric: std dev of cutoff freq across windows

nodes.title: Approach B: Cross-Frequency Coherence (CFCC)
nodes.description: Measure correlation between adjacent frequency bands. MP3=sudden decorrelation at cliff. Tape=gradual decorrelation

nodes.title: Approach A requires per-window cutoff detection
nodes.description: Need to find -20dB point in each FFT window, track frequency, calc std dev. Adds complexity but gives strong signal for variance

nodes.title: Approach B detects cliff via decorrelation
nodes.description: Measures correlation between adjacent bands. Cliff = sudden drop >0.25. Works with existing FFT data structure

nodes.title: Implemented CFCC in commit aa464b6
nodes.description: Added CrossFrequencyCoherence struct, cliff detection at known codec cutoffs, +25 for cfcc_cliff, -15 for lofi_safe_natural_rolloff

nodes.title: CFCC passes 157 tests, detects 25/29 transcodes
nodes.description: Test results: 25 TRANSCODE, 3 SUSPECT, 1 OK (AAC decoder issue). Approach B chosen and implemented

nodes.title: Code organization: consider splitting large files
nodes.description: ui.html, graph_ui.html, spectral.rs are getting large. May want to modularize: separate CSS, split analysis components, use proper build tooling

nodes.title: MP3 vs Tape: MP3 has brick-wall cutoff at fixed freq, tape has gradual rolloff that varies with dynamics
nodes.description: Core insight: MP3 encoders apply same filter everywhere, analog rolloff is content-dependent

nodes.title: CFCC scoring: +25 cfcc_cliff, +15 decorrelation_spike, -15 lofi_safe_natural_rolloff
nodes.description: Cliff threshold >0.25 drop in correlation between adjacent bands

nodes.title: Known codec cutoffs: 64-96k=10.5-12kHz, 128k=14-16.5kHz, 192k=16.5-18.5kHz, 256k=18-19.5kHz, 320k=19.5-21kHz
nodes.description: Used for matching detected cliffs to likely source bitrates

Site structure and content organization

nodes.description: 5 pages, interactive demo with real DB, ready for merge and Pages enablement

nodes.title: Client-side WASM analyzer - upload tracks, analyze in browser, no server
nodes.description: Compile Rust to WebAssembly, run FFT analysis client-side, piggyback on GitHub Pages hosting

nodes.title: WASM compilation approach
nodes.description: How to get Rust audio analysis running in the browser

nodes.title: Full Rust to WASM (wasm-pack)
nodes.description: Compile entire analyzer with symphonia+rustfft to wasm32-unknown-unknown. Symphonia may have issues with no-std

nodes.title: Hybrid: JS audio decode + Rust FFT in WASM
nodes.description: Use Web Audio API for decoding, pass PCM to Rust WASM for spectral analysis. More compatible, proven approach

nodes.title: Pure JS port
nodes.description: Translate detection algorithms to JavaScript. Use existing JS FFT libraries. Maximum compatibility, no WASM complexity

nodes.title: Homebrew Rust lacks wasm32 target - need rustup or manual install
nodes.description: wasm-pack requires wasm32-unknown-unknown target which isn't in Homebrew's Rust sysroot

nodes.title: How to get WASM built without local rustup
nodes.description: Options: install rustup locally, use GitHub Actions CI, or pure JS fallback

nodes.title: GitHub Actions builds WASM
nodes.description: CI workflow compiles wasm-analyzer, commits to gh-pages branch. Local dev doesn't need rustup

nodes.title: How to handle multi-user graph sync
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feature/multi-user-graph-sync","confidence":75,"prompt":"Core problem: multiple users have local .deciduous/deciduous.db, need to sync changes to shared repo without conflicts"}

nodes.title: Option A: JSON diff files - export new nodes/edges as JSON patches
Option B: Git-like content-addressable storage - hash nodes by content
Option C: UUID-based node IDs - globally unique, no conflicts
Option D: Hybrid - UUIDs for new nodes, stable refs for existing nodes
jj (Jujutsu) uses change IDs vs commit IDs - change IDs are stable across rebases
jj key insight: change IDs are stable across rebases, separate from commit IDs. Uses bit-reversed commit ID for git-imported commits
Option E: jj-inspired - UUID 'change_id' per node, separate from integer 'id', stable across sync
Choosing Option E: jj-inspired dual-ID model
